thread.title: 'We're powerless': Traditional owners discuss constitutional recognition
thread.title_full: 'We're powerless': Traditional owners discuss constitutional recognition

author: Avani Dias
title: 'We're powerless': Traditional owners discuss constitutional recognition
text:
Traditional owners across the Top End have held a historical meeting to discuss constitutional recognition, 50 years since Australians voted to recognise Aboriginal rights for the first time. 
More than one 100 traditional owners met in Darwin as part of the Indigenous-led Referendum Council meetings. 
The aim is to determine the process for a proposed national referendum on recognising Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people in the constitution. 
"We're not recognised, that's the problem, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people are almost invisible," Alyawarre woman and co-chair of the Referendum Council, Pat Anderson said. 
"We're not in the constitution ... we have no power, we are powerless, nobody has to talk to us about anything and successive governments don't. 
"We're hopeful that by amending the constitution, we can be properly recognised â€” we're not talking about a plaque in the constitution or some kind of poetry, we're looking for substantive change." Meeting named 'historic' by attendees 
Local conveners of the event said the meeting had been a historical moment. 
"This would be the first time that the [people] in that room ... have been together," Coburg Peninsula traditional owner and co-convener of the convention, John Christopherson said. 
Mr Christopherson said constitutional recognition, a treaty, statehood, and land rights were some of the main topics discussed. 
"Most importantly is that our lives are governed by a piece of legislation that's at the whim and fancy of whatever government is in power," he said. 
"So if we have a hostile government tomorrow that doesn't like that we are saying, whatever wins we have made can be wiped out. 
"So it's important that we have this discussion and come up with a position that is meaningful, it is beneficial, and it is enduring for Aboriginal people." Indigenous organisations led by Indigenous people 
Former Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission member Josie Crawshaw said Top End traditional owners wanted robust Indigenous organisations led by Indigenous people. Photo: The National Indigenous Constitutional Convention will be held at Uluru in May. (AAP) 
"In the Northern Territory, [constitutional recognition] would address land rights, it would address statehood, it would address us having our own organisations and probably a body that would be able to have a financial package that helps us to be more self-determining and run our own services," she said. 
"Because at the moment it's basically done by a non-Aboriginal industry and very little of the Aboriginal dollar gets to the ground on the communities." 
Ms Crawshaw said there were strong views among the group on a treaty and it could emerge that constitutional recognition could set up a treaty process and the establishment of a treaty commission. 
"But there's also strong views about having representation in designated seats in Parliament, there's also strong views about having a body that is enshrined in constitution that can't be closed down like ATSIC and other bodies that have gone before that," she said. 
Ms Anderson said there was a push in the dialogues for the survival of Aboriginal languages, for Aboriginal Studies to be taught in schools around the country, and the maintenance of culture and spirituality. 
She said these issues could be addressed if constitutional recognition were to occur. 
"We'll have some power to influence what happens in schools and what have you, otherwise we wouldn't be doing this if we weren't going to have any influence," she said. 
The Referendum Council will continue to hold dialogues around the country with an aim to reach consensus on the issues. 
There will then be a National Indigenous Constitutional Convention at Uluru in May, where a recommendation will be made for a report to the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. 
"We are eternally optimistic that governments will act on what it is we are proposing, history has shown us it is very difficult to get governments to act on what we want," Mr Christopherson said. 
"There is nice words and a lot of things that are said but we need something to be done, not waffle about what they think is something that should be done."
